questions.question: Question 1: Which among the following is the first mediator to be released during inflammation?
questions.explanation:
Serotonin and histamine are among the first mediators to be released during inflammation. 
They are stored as preformed molecules in cells. Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine) is a preformed vasoactive mediator that is present in platelets 
and certain neuroendocrine cells, such as in the gastrointestinal tract. Its functions include 
vasoconstriction and neurotransmitter action in the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following may serve as a source of histamine production?
questions.explanation:
The sources of histamine include platelets, basophils, and mast cells (major source). Preformed histamine is stored in the granules of mast cells and other cells. It is released by 
degranulation in response to a variety of stimuli, including: • Physical injuries - trauma, cold, or heat • Binding of antibodies to mast cells • Products of complement called anaphylatoxins (C3a and C5a) Its vasoactive effects are mediated mainly via binding to H1 receptors on microvascular 
endothelial cells. The functions of histamine include: • Vasodilation • Increased vascular permeability • Endothelial activation

questions.question:
Question 3: The release of arachidonic acid from the membrane phospholipids is mainly mediated by 
which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The release of arachidonic acid (AA) from the membrane phospholipids is mainly mediated by 
phospholipase A2 and C. AA is a polyunsaturated fatty acid that may be derived from the following sources: • Dietary sources 96 
Sold by @itachibot • From the conversion of the essential fatty acid linoleic acid • From membrane phospholipids via phospholipase A2 and C (in response to mechanical, 
chemical, or physical stimuli) • From diacylglycerol by the action of diacylglycerol lipase AA-derived mediators are also called eicosanoids (20-carbon fatty acids). They are synthesized by 
two major classes of enzymes: • Cyclooxygenases - produces prostaglandins • Lipoxygenases - produces leukotrienes and lipoxins These mediators bind to G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) on many cell types. They stimulate 
vascular and cellular reactions in acute inflammation.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements about prostaglandins is false?

options.a: TxA2 is the major product in platelets
options.b: Prostacyclin is a vasodilator and inhibits platelet aggregation
options.c: PGD2 is the major prostaglandin produced by mast cells

questions.explanation:
Prostacyclin synthase is present in the vascular endothelium. It is responsible for the formation of prostacyclin (PGI2) and PGF1a (its stable end 
product). Prostacyclin is a vasodilator and a potent inhibitor of platelet aggregation. Thromboxane synthase is present in platelets, and hence, TxA2 is the major product in these cells. PGD2 is the major prostaglandin produced by mast cells and is a chemoattractant for neutrophils. 97 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding leukotrienes?

options.a: They are produced by leukocytes and mast cells by action of lipoxygenase
options.b: 5-lipoxygenase is the predominant enzyme in neutrophils
options.c: LTB4 is a potent chemotactic agent and activator of neutrophils
options.d: Leukotrienes are less potent mediators of bronchospasm

questions.explanation:
Leukotrienes are more potent than histamine in increasing vascular permeability and causing 
bronchospasm. They are produced by leukocytes and mast cells from arachidonic acid by the action of 
lipoxygenase. They are involved in vascular and smooth muscle reactions. There are three 
different lipoxygenases (5, 12, 15). 5-lipoxygenase is predominant in neutrophils. The principal actions of various arachidonic acid metabolites in inflammation are as follows: Eicosanoid

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is an anti-inflammatory cytokine?
questions.explanation:
IL-4 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine. It induces alternatively activated macrophages. This results in tissue repair and the resolution of 
inflammation. The following are anti-inflammatory cytokines: • IL-4 • IL-10 • IL-13 • TGF- • Lipoxins Lipoxins suppress inflammation by inhibiting leukocyte recruitment. They inhibit neutrophil 
chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium.

specific types of leukocytes. They are classified into 4 groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the 
proteins. This is given in the image and the table below. 99

questions.question: Question 9: Fractalkine belongs to which chemokine family?
questions.explanation:
Fractalkine is the only known member of the CX3C chemokine group. CX3C chemokines contain 3 amino acids between the 2 cysteines. This chemokine exists in two forms: • Cell surface-bound protein - • Induced on endothelial cells by inflammatory cytokines • Promotes the strong adhesion of monocytes and T cells 100 
Sold by @itachibot • Soluble form - • Derived by proteolysis of the membrane-bound protein • Potent chemoattractant activity for the same cell. The image below shows the structure of CX3C chemokine.

questions.question: Question 10: What type of chemokine is MCP-1?
questions.explanation:
MCP-1 belongs to the CC type of chemokine. Here, the first two conserved cysteine residues 
remain adjacent to each other. The CC chemokines include: • Monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP1) • Eotaxin • Macrophage inflammatory protein1 (MIP1) • Regulated and normal T-cell expressed and secreted (RANTES) The image below shows the structure of C-C chemokine: 101 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Serum concentrations of which of the following decrease during inflammation?
questions.explanation:
During inflammation, there are reduced levels of albumin. This occurs in order to allow an increase in the liver's capacity to synthesize acute phase reactants. 
Hence, albumin is called a negative phase reactant. Negative acute-phase proteins concentration decreases during inflammation. These are: • Albumin • Transferrin • Retinol-binding protein • Antithrombin • Transcortin • Alpha 2-HS glycoprotein • Alpha-fetoprotein • Thyroxin-binding protein • Insulin-like growth factor 1 • Factor 12 Acute-phase proteins are plasma proteins synthesized by the liver in response to inflammation. 
These include C-reactive protein (CRP), fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A (SAA) protein. The 
synthesis of these molecules in hepatocytes is stimulated by cytokines. IL-6 stimulates the 
synthesis of CRP and fibrinogen and IL-1 or TNF for SAA.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 39-year-old woman is being evaluated for anemia. She is a known case of rheumatoid 
arthritis. Increased levels of which of the following is responsible for her anemia?
questions.explanation:
102 
Sold by @itachibot In this scenario, the woman has a chronic illness, rheumatoid arthritis. In chronic disease states, 
elevated plasma concentrations of hepcidin cause anemia. Increased hepcidin reduces the 
availability of iron. Fibrinogen binds to red cells and causes rouleaux formation. They sediment more rapidly at unit 
gravity than do individual red cells. This is the basis for measuring the erythrocyte sedimentation 
rate in inflammation. C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A (SAA) bind to microbial cell walls. They act as 
opsonins and fix complement. They also bind chromatin.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements is not true for platelet-activating factor?

options.a: It is secreted by mast cells
options.d: It is involved in leukocyte adhesion

questions.explanation:
Platelet-activating factor (PAF) primarily causes vasoconstriction. PAF is a phospholipid-derived mediator known to have multiple inflammatory effects. It may be 
secreted by the following: • Platelets • Basophils • Mast cells • Neutrophils • Macrophages • Endothelial cells. Its functions include: • Platelet aggregation • Vasoconstriction • Bronchoconstriction • Leukocyte adhesion • Vascular permeability and vasodilation at low doses

questions.question: Question 14: The critical step in complement activation involves the proteolysis of the which component?
questions.explanation:
The critical step in complement activation is the proteolysis of the third (and most abundant) 
component, C3. The complement system can be activated by one of three pathways: • Classical pathway - antibody-mediated and triggered by fixation of C1 to antibody (IgM or IgG) 
that has combined with antigen • Alternative pathway - triggered by microbial surface molecules in the absence of antibody 103 
Sold by @itachibot • Lectin pathway - plasma mannose-binding lectin binds to carbohydrates on microbes and 
directly activates C1. All three pathways of complement activation lead to the formation of an active enzyme called the 
C3 convertase. It splits C3 into two functionally distinct fragments, C3a and C3b.

questions.question: Question 15: Patients with an inherited deficiency of C1 inhibitor will have which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The deficiency of C1 INH causes hereditary angioedema. C1-inhibitor (C1 INH)is the largest member of the serpin superfamily of proteins. It normally 
inhibits the following: • Complement system • Kallikrein system • Factor XII or Hageman factor Deficiency of C1 INH is associated with hereditary angioedema (hereditary angioneurotic 
edema). It leads to decreased C4 and C2 levels and bradykinin accumulation. There is swelling 
due to leakage of fluid from blood vessels into connective tissue. It is an autosomal dominant 
disorder.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not caused by bradykinin?

options.c: Pain at the site of injection

questions.explanation:
Bradykinin results in vasodilation. Kinins are vasoactive peptides derived from plasma proteins called kininogens, by the action of 
specific proteases called kallikreins. The enzyme kallikrein cleaves high molecular weight 
kininogen, to produce bradykinin. Actions of bradykinin: • Increases vascular permeability • Potent vasodilator • Contraction of smooth muscle • Dilation of blood vessels • Pain when injected into the skin

questions.question: Question 18: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except:
questions.explanation:
Histamine is involved in the mediation of vascular events of inflammation, not fever. Fever is characterized by an elevation of body temperature, usually by 1° to 4°C. It is one of the 
most prominent manifestations of the acute-phase response, especially if associated with 
infection. Substances that induce fever are called pyrogens. They may be exogenous or endogenous. • Endogenous pyrogens - IL-1, TNF, prostaglandins • Exogenous pyrogens - • Lipopolysaccharides of bacterial walls • They stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous pyrogens (IL-1 and TNF) Cytokines result in an increase in cyclooxygenases that convert arachidonic acid into 
prostaglandins. These prostaglandins are produced in the vascular and perivascular cells of the 
hypothalamus. In the hypothalamus, they stimulate the production of neurotransmitters that 
reset the temperature setpoint to a higher level. This is especially by PGE2.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is true about fever?

options.a: Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
options.b: PGD2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level
options.d: Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine

questions.explanation:
IL-1 is an endogenous pyrogen Substances that induce fever are called pyrogens. They may be exogenous or endogenous. • Endogenous pyrogens - IL-1, TNF, prostaglandins • Exogenous pyrogens - • Lipopolysaccharides of bacterial walls • They stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous pyrogens (IL-1 and TNF) 105 
Sold by @itachibot In the hypothalamus, prostaglandins such as PGE2 stimulate the production of neurotransmitters 
that reset the temperature setpoint at a higher level. Aspirin decreases fever by inhibiting 
prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.question: Question 20: IL-1 is activated by :
questions.explanation:
Caspase- 1 activates the biologically active form of IL-1. IL-1 is involved in pyroptosis, a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis 
and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. It occurs in the 
following sequence: • Activation of the inflammasome complex • Activation of caspase-1 • Generation of IL-1 - results in fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is not secreted by T-helper type 2 cells?
questions.explanation:
TH2 cells secrete IL4, IL5, and IL13. Three subsets of CD4+ T cells secrete different types of cytokines and elicit different types of 
inflammation.

questions.question:
Question 22: In patients with which of the following conditions would you observe tertiary lymphoid 
organs?
questions.explanation:
Tertiary lymphoid organs are seen in autoimmune conditions such as: • Hashimoto thyroiditis - in the thyroid • Rheumatoid arthritis - in the synovium • SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) - in the kidneys Tertiary lymphoid organs are a feature of chronic inflammatory conditions. Here, the 
accumulated lymphocytes, antigen-presenting cells, and plasma cells cluster together to form 
lymphoid tissues resembling lymph nodes.

questions.question:
Question 23: Lymph node biopsy of a patient with tuberculosis demonstrated the following findings. From 
which of the following are these cells derived? 93 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given histopathological findings in a patient with tuberculosis are suggestive 
of granulomatous inflammation, with epithelioid and multinucleated giant cells. These cells are 
derived from the monocyte-macrophage lineage. 106 
Sold by @itachibot Macrophages activated by IFN- develop into cells with abundant cytoplasm. They resemble 
epithelial cells and are thus called epithelioid cells. Some activated macrophages may fuse, 
forming multinucleated giant cells. Collections of activated macrophages, often with T 
lymphocytes are seen in granulomatous inflammation. Sometimes it is associated with central 
caseating necrosis. Granulomas may be formed in response to various stimuli: • Immune granulomas - due to T-cell mediated response; macrophages activate T cells to produce 
cytokines, such as IL-2 and IFN- • Foreign body granulomas - due to inert foreign bodies in the absence of a T-cell mediated 
response

questions.question: Question 24: Epithelioid granulomas are not seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation:
107 
Sold by @itachibot Kikuchi's lymphadenitis is associated with histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis. It does not show 
epithelioid granulomatous lesions. Common conditions characterized by epithelioid granuloma formation: • Tuberculosis • Sarcoidosis (non-caseating granuloma) • Brucellosis • Cat scratch disease (stellate shaped or round granuloma) • Syphilis (gumma ) • Lymphogranuloma inguinale • Leprosy • Inflammatory bowel disease • Toxoplasmosis

questions.question:
Question 25: A pathologist observes the given findings during the examination of a lymph node sample. 
Which of the following is the least likely cause?
questions.explanation:
The given histopathological image of a lymph node shows a non-caseating granuloma. 
Tuberculosis is least likely as it is commonly associated with caseating granulomas. Non-caseating granulomas can be seen in the following conditions: • Leprosy • Cat-scratch disease • Sarcoidosis • Berylliosis • Crohn's disease • Hypersenitive pneumonitis • Foreign body granuloma • Q fever • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's). • Hodgkin's lymphoma

questions.question: Question 26: Stellate granuloma is seen in :
questions.explanation:
Stellate granuloma is seen in cat-scratch disease. It is also known as subacute regional 
lymphadenitis. It is a bacterial infection caused by Bartonella henselae. It is acquired following contact with 
infected animals (commonly cats). 108 
Sold by @itachibot Regional lymph nodes demonstrate: • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas) • Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells 109 
Sold by @itachibot Tissue Repair
